newsitem.title: USA: LILCO warns that window for LIPA pact is closing.
newsitem.headline: LILCO warns that window for LIPA pact is closing.

text.p: The head of Long Island Lighting Co on Wednesday warned state lawmakers that the opportunity to conclude a partial state takeover of the firm, which is merging with Brooklyn Union Gas, was fleeting.

W.J. Catacosinos, chairman and chief executive officer of LILCO, in prepared remarks, said: "As you examine this proposal, please keep in mind that the benefits of this plan result largely from LIPA's tax-exempt status, and that there is a window of opportunity to take advantage of LIPA's tax exemption, and that window is rapidly closing."
He was referring to the Long Island Power Authority (LIPA).

The head of LILCO made his comments to the Democrat-led state Assembly. Its Speaker, Sheldon Silver, D-Manhattan, has raised a number of questions about the deal, which would be funded by an approximately $7.3 billion sale of tax-exempt bonds--the nation's largest such offering.

A spokeswoman for the company explained that LILCO feared the Internal Revenue Service might approve a new rule that would impose a big capital gains tax, which could derail the deal. "Basically, the concern is that the I.R.S. is going to pass a new regulation and that new regulation would require the transaction to have a $2 billion capital gains tax."

When LIPA and the companies announced the deal in mid-March, Frank Zarb, the LIPA chairman who since then has stepped down, explained that a waiver on federal capital gains taxes would be a key to the success of the agency's plans to buy utility assets from Brooklyn Union Gas and LILCO. He added LIPA faced a June deadline for submitting all its paperwork to the I.R.S.
